This is one of those great games where you think, "Why didn't I play this sooner?". Divinity Original Sin 2 (DOS2) is the sequel to the already acclaimed DOS by Larian, who are also responsible for Baldur's Gate 3 and all Divinity games. The lore is excellent and everything in the game fits together; it's incredible how even the side quests offer more depth. The graphics are better, more detailed; every piece of equipment is more beautiful than the last, and each item adapts to the race‚Äîthe same helmet, for example, will have a different look for each character when equipped.

Exploration is rewarding. There's no grind here, but it will help you reach the recommended level for the tougher battles, besides opening up alternatives to solve the main quests.

The soundtrack is incredibly good. I recommend choosing Lohse as a companion for a wonderful surprise at the end of her personal quest.

In short, it was more than 200 hours well spent, and I'm rooting for Larian to release the third game with the improvements made in BG3.

Boy, did I hate the original Original Sin. Uninteresting protagonists with gratingly chirpy voice acting, needless and annoying pixel hunting-based "puzzles", a mandatory and tedious world-wide Easter egg hunt before progressing to the game's final stage, DOS1 had it all, where "it" is anything that makes you want to claw to the bottom of your eye cavities.

Is DOS2 any better? Hell yes. But annoyingly, it has its own bagful of crappy design decisions. First, and worst of all, behold the tonnage of stupid, obscure, burdensome puzzles that quagmire pacing. I am a self-identified point and click adventure enjoyer. I even have a fondness for the genre's janky, non-intuitive riddles. And still DOS2 manages to make me seethe with its sloppy, crappy, time-dumpstering, no good, joy-impeding brain teasers (described as such because they make you want to tease your brain out of your skull with an elephant gun). By the game's third act, if I spent more than 30 seconds puzzling over a garbage mental challenge, straight to a Wiki I went for the answer, because fuuuuck that. 

Second, it's disappointing how much DOS2 revolves around CC'ing your oppenents before they can CC you. When the latter happens, boy is it a drawn out spectator shart of an experience whereby you sit idly for a few minutes waiting for the the punchline that is inevitably a Game Over screen. 

Can you build your party around this CC-incentivized combat system? Of course. The easiest path is to make your characters focus exclusively in either Physical or Magic-based damage, and to Glass Cannon-ize every last one of them. Is it enjoyable to do so? Well not when I feel forced to. 

Overall, DOS2's story, main cast of characters and voice acting are all loads better than its predecessor. But I played this whole damn game with an undercurrent of annoyance that neither BG3, Tyranny, Shadowrun, Pillars, nor Disco Elysium subjected me to.

So after sinking way too many hours into this game (and restarting like five times because I can‚Äôt decide on a class), I can safely say Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of the best RPGs I‚Äôve ever played. It‚Äôs the kind of game where you tell yourself ‚ÄúI‚Äôll just play for 30 minutes,‚Äù and suddenly it‚Äôs 3am and you‚Äôre arguing with a talking skeleton about morality.

‚úî The Good Stuff

The combat is amazing. It‚Äôs turn-based but super creative ‚Äî every fight feels like a puzzle. You can set the floor on fire, electrify puddles, teleport enemies off cliffs‚Ä¶ basically, if something looks like it might do damage, it probably will. The game really rewards experimenting, and sometimes accidentally blowing up your own team (it happens more often than I‚Äôd like to admit).

The story and characters are great too. Everyone has their own weird backstory, and the choices you make actually matter. You can talk your way out of fights, cheese bosses with clever tactics, or just cause chaos because you felt like it. There‚Äôs a lot of freedom, almost too much ‚Äî I kept getting distracted by random quests I found while snooping around people‚Äôs houses.

Also, co-op is a blast. It‚Äôs rare to find a game where you can play a full RPG with a friend and have the world react to both of you. Half the fun is watching your buddy pick dialogue options that get the whole party in trouble.

‚ö† The Annoying Stuff

It‚Äôs definitely not a casual game. The learning curve is pretty steep, especially in the beginning. The game hands you a spoon, a stick, and a piece of string and expects you to figure out how to survive. Also, inventory management is‚Ä¶ a lot. Thank god for backpacks.

Difficulty spikes can be rough too. One minute you‚Äôre wiping the floor with enemies, and the next you walk into the wrong area and get deleted in one turn.

üéØ Final Thoughts

If you love deep RPGs with tons of freedom, tactical combat, and the occasional moment of ‚Äúwait, did I really just set my own team on fire?‚Äù, this is absolutely worth playing. It‚Äôs a big, messy, fun, insanely detailed game that rewards you for thinking outside the box. Not perfect, but honestly pretty close.

I give Divinity: Original Sin 2 a narrow yes.

The pros:

[list]
    [*]Core gameplay that is a technical marvel
    [*]Characters who are immediately engaging and memorable
    [*]Beautiful art and setting
    [*]Very open-ended and non-linear
[/list]

The cons:

[list]
    [*]Broken learning curve--the game expects players to play through on an easy difficulty first because players are not informed early on of pivotal (and usually non-standard) factors later in the game, and it is a long ways into the game before players can respec (unless they use an add-on which disables achievements).
    [*]The combat is novel but the novelty breaks down after a while.  It's cool that players can effectively "hack" the game, but combat reaches the point where players need to repeat the same hacks over and over again.  Combat relying on hacks isn't as robust as more vanilla combat systems.
    [*]The over-arching story is creative but I personally don't like it.  However, I do enjoy the main character's side-stories.  Like many games these days, I wish the narrative stuck more to personal drama than grasping for cosmic drama.
[/list]

The start at Fort Joy is amazing to play. It's the best balanced and the most well-rounded. I always knew where to go, always found new things to explore and I never felt lost story wise.

All of this starts to turn around in the following acts and I feel like it gets worse or at least more glaring the further you progress. 
These glaring issues for me are:

[b] "Open World" [/b]
On Fort Joy the open world felt rewarding. The battles were challenging but beatable. So, I was delighted to see what may come after Fort Joy.

What I ended up finding were "natural" level barriers that forced my friend and I to follow a linear route to so that we could beat the battles (note that we played on normal).
Finding this linear route after the game told us to pick and choose where we wish to go next just felt confusing. In total it took us a month to progress (we played once every week). We desperately staked out which area might be appropriate for our level 12 characters. I still remember each area of the second act and which level is associated with. 
Perhaps we where unfortunate to not have chosen this path. Mayhaps, we simply overread an important dialog pointing us towards the right direction.
The only thing I know for sure is that the only for us beatable area was [spoiler]in the top left corner[/spoiler] of the map.

You have to pass multiple other areas with higher levels to get there.
Nevertheless, this area was still a mighty struggle. We fought with everything we had. We strategized about each battle. After every loss we took notes, regrouped and attacked again. Every potential "exploit" we could see, we utilized.

This level of tenacity does not feel appropriate for a normal difficulty playthrough at least not for me.

[u]Recommendation[/u]
The pre-set levels with the exponential leveling system to not work together with the "open world" aspect of the game.
I'll get more in-depth with the leveling in the next part, but giving the player the directive to "reign freely" while setting fixed levels to the enemies does not add up. 
Adjusting the enemies to the level the player is feels way more appropriate. Maybe, sprinkle in some fixed levels as a boss to really stop the player if the story demands it, but putting this everywhere is just misguided. 

Especially since it let to us loosing track of the story completely. We started each quests, but we could never finish them due to the battles. So after a week or two we came back to the quest without having a clue of what was going on. (The in-game journal is quite lack luster on this regard)

[b]Levelling[/b]
In total you can get up to level [spoiler]21[/spoiler], which feels a little low looking at other RPGs. The issue I have with this is that you are at level [spoiler]12 when leaving Fort Joy[/spoiler]. This leads to the weird situation that levels are exponentially more important the closer you get to the max level.

At first you may be able to win a battle against a two levels higher foe, but towards the end if you are not on the same level as your enemy, you get demolished.
We literally couldn't defeat the final boss since we were one level below it. Coincidentally, we also were at a point were we felt like we completed every quest available to us. After trying for another fruitless three weeks, we loaded a previous save and tried to squeeze out another level so we have even an inkling of a chance.

As a [u]recommendation[/u] I can just offer a proper re-balancing of the later areas and a plead for general level cap increase. In the last stages of the game seeing the next level XP requirement to be in the millions is disheartening.

[b]Quest Management[/b]
A more minute point but it feels like the bad cherry on top of the issue cake. 
The in-game journal feels in-adequate to help the player remember story points and even gist's of quests. The best you can hope for is a red marker on your map, and a small to-do entry. The point of the quest, the afflicted affiliations and the severity are often not included. 

Especially after our 3-week excursion through level barrier hell, we essentially reached a point of mindless "red flag grinding". I at least felt like a zombie trying to stave my XP-hunger by any means possible. So, every found quest was like a 3-star prepared meal and I devoured it as far as I could, but the chef seemed to hate me and always put glass shards in the food so that I had to come back to it later after my gums were accustomed to the "difficulty" (Essentially I needed to level to beat a foe)

Everything combined together let to me loosing completely any inkling of the story.

A small anecdote concerning story. My friend and I felt like we managed to skip great chunks of it unwillingly. One example for this is the story around Gareth.

For me it felt as follows: [spoiler]The great leader Gareth managed to escape the prison island Fort Joy with the help of his divine acquaintances (us). Together they set sail to Reaper's Coast where Gareth's parents resided. He immediately went to his parents but Magisters seemed to have been a step ahead of him. The battle did not take long, but neither did the triumph. Beneath rubble lay two corpses ... his parents. Silently he buried them. A deep anger begins taking hold of Gareth. Before he could do anything reckless his two divine acquaintances appear. He told them what happened. The trio stood there silently. Until one divine spoke up: "It is what it is, bro".

These words quiet the anger immediately and Gareth went back to the ship never do to anything of note again.
[/spoiler] 

I do not know how one should experience his tale but this is beyond ridiculous.

I had a very unique problem with gear throughout the whole game. Namely, I was often stuck with too low leveled gear because of set combos. These set combos gave me unique traits which I liked, but I could never transition smoothly to a new set due to bonuses of the set combo.

I re-iterate my final gear that was a 5 piece armor set, was physically not possible to be upgraded fully ONCE even if I collected ALL the armor upgrade ingredients.

[u]Recommendation[/u]: Please let me upgrade my gear, I'm begging you.

Possibly one of the most frustrating games I've ever played. I did a full two player run with a friend on Classic difficulty, start to finish. After having played through BG3 twice and enjoying it, I expected this game to feel similar. Do not make that mistake.
This game has major balancing issues, but not combat wise, but knowledge wise. If you go into this game knowing and looking up everything, you'll probably clear it all no problem, but going into this game blind will result in you getting your ass handed to you. Surprise encounters out the wazoo, enemy immunities that can screw up a majority of builds, the physical/magical split. Oh and some of the puzzles are absolutely idiotic. Then there's the add-ons, fantastic additions if you don't care about achievements, but if you do, you gotta keep em off, which really sucks given they're all QoL things that exist to make this boring game significantly less frustrating. Want to be able to see ghosts without clicking a button? Tough luck, no achievements for you. Want to replenish a resource that isn't hard to get but takes like 20 seconds at the end of each fight to replenish at the click of a button? No achievements allowed.
Also lets talk about build variety. And how it sucks. Do you want a hybrid magic/physical guy? Enjoy gimping yourself. Heck, do you want half mage half physical team members? Enjoy gimping your team. You pretty much have to go all in on one type by the end of the game because of the game's magic/physical armour health system. Oh and you better hope you get good levelled gear on level, or your armor will be too low and this game becomes CC hell, because almost every ability has an unavoidable CC once your armor is gone.
Also by the end of the game, you better have at least 5 points in polymorph if you want to do anything, cause if you don't, good luck with your builds.
Also civil skills are stupid. Maybe if you got more points it wouldn't be as dumb, but lockpicking eats lockpicks success or failure, same with identifying, so you better have a mask of the shapeshifter or an undead in the party if you don't want to deal with that crap.
Finally, ignoring balancing issues, enemies regularly jumping out of nowhere to fight you, the fact that the game has levelled randomized loot, the weirdly rushed ending to many story arcs and the fact that the game tells you nothing, the game is broken. This is a good game, but hear me out. 

This is a negative review because the game has insanely high review scores BUT it has some glaring issues. 

There's a bit of a catch though. It's the fact that I've only become frustrated enough to leave a negative review after multiple playthrough's. This is because I was so pleased with my initial experience that I was willing to overlook the issues back then. I am not willing now. 

The worst issue here is the simple fact that many fights in this game feel borderline unwinnable unless you already know how the fight will go before going into it and take steps to give yourself as much advantage as possible. This doesn't feel like "tactical" gameplay and is very frustrating, probably the most of any of the issues this game has. 

The second biggest issue is that you can really easily screw yourself over just because you talked to someone with the wrong character, which btw can be very hard to avoid in certain situations where npc's approach and initiate dialogue after a fight or something. They just go for the nearest npc and you can't well control that. If you are playing with friends, this mostly manifests as the player with the character who has persuasion having to be the one who goes first everywhere to talk to all npc's and see all new areas, otherwise you might fail some essential dialogue option. Feels like it punishes the other players for exploring.  

The rest of the issues have mostly to do with jank or bugs, like quest entries and markers not updating properly (this happens ALOT, but thankfully actual quest progression rarely breaks). But one of my biggest personal issues is the fact that many near-essential game changes that come bundled with the game and were made by the devs are treated as mods and disable your achievements. Like, really? Almost all of them are quality of life improvements that should have just been part of the base game, don't get me wrong it's extra nice to have the option, but not if it punishes you for using them. 

It's a good game, and you probably owe it to yourself to play it if you are a fan of crpg's, BUT it still has issues which may not be conveyed to you by the high review score. That's why I decided to write this.

Ah yes one final thing. Traps in this game are on a limited, short timer, which counts independent of the combat turns. They are fucking useless. Absolute garbage and waste, baffling design decision that I still struggle to comprehend. Normally I love a good use of traps in games like this (Underrail is the absolute king of this plus also stealth) but in this game it is awful. But that may be just me, cause I'm a traps enjoyer.

Not enjoying the combat system. It's doable but I don't enjoy how it creates challenge. Also, the game world is supremely bleak and depressing; I don't need a game for that.

I really would love to like this game. It has engaging combat, a great multiplayer and interactivity that I have not seen before.
The start at Fort Joy is amazing to play. It's the best balanced and the most well-rounded. I always knew where to go, always found new things to explore and I never felt lost story wise.

All of this starts to turn around in the following acts and I feel like it gets worse or at least more glaring the further you progress. 
These glaring issues for me are:

[b] "Open World" [/b]
On Fort Joy the open world felt rewarding. The battles were challenging but beatable. So, I was delighted to see what may come after Fort Joy.

What I ended up finding were "natural" level barriers that forced my friend and I to follow a linear route to so that we could beat the battles (note that we played on normal).
Finding this linear route after the game told us to pick and choose where we wish to go next just felt confusing. In total it took us a month to progress (we played once every week). We desperately staked out which area might be appropriate for our level 12 characters. I still remember each area of the second act and which level is associated with. 
Perhaps we where unfortunate to not have chosen this path. Mayhaps, we simply overread an important dialog pointing us towards the right direction.
The only thing I know for sure is that the only for us beatable area was [spoiler]in the top left corner[/spoiler] of the map.

You have to pass multiple other areas with higher levels to get there.
Nevertheless, this area was still a mighty struggle. We fought with everything we had. We strategized about each battle. After every loss we took notes, regrouped and attacked again. Every potential "exploit" we could see, we utilized.

This level of tenacity does not feel appropriate for a normal difficulty playthrough at least not for me.

[u]Recommendation[/u]
The pre-set levels with the exponential leveling system to not work together with the "open world" aspect of the game.
I'll get more in-depth with the leveling in the next part, but giving the player the directive to "reign freely" while setting fixed levels to the enemies does not add up. 
Adjusting the enemies to the level the player is feels way more appropriate. Maybe, sprinkle in some fixed levels as a boss to really stop the player if the story demands it, but putting this everywhere is just misguided. 

Especially since it let to us loosing track of the story completely. We started each quests, but we could never finish them due to the battles. So after a week or two we came back to the quest without having a clue of what was going on. (The in-game journal is quite lack luster on this regard)

[b]Levelling[/b]
In total you can get up to level [spoiler]21[/spoiler], which feels a little low looking at other RPGs. The issue I have with this is that you are at level [spoiler]12 when leaving Fort Joy[/spoiler]. This leads to the weird situation that levels are exponentially more important the closer you get to the max level.

At first you may be able to win a battle against a two levels higher foe, but towards the end if you are not on the same level as your enemy, you get demolished.
We literally couldn't defeat the final boss since we were one level below it. Coincidentally, we also were at a point were we felt like we completed every quest available to us. After trying for another fruitless three weeks, we loaded a previous save and tried to squeeze out another level so we have even an inkling of a chance.

As a [u]recommendation[/u] I can just offer a proper re-balancing of the later areas and a plead for general level cap increase. In the last stages of the game seeing the next level XP requirement to be in the millions is disheartening.

[b]Quest Management[/b]
A more minute point but it feels like the bad cherry on top of the issue cake. 
The in-game journal feels in-adequate to help the player remember story points and even gist's of quests. The best you can hope for is a red marker on your map, and a small to-do entry. The point of the quest, the afflicted affiliations and the severity are often not included. 

Especially after our 3-week excursion through level barrier hell, we essentially reached a point of mindless "red flag grinding". I at least felt like a zombie trying to stave my XP-hunger by any means possible. So, every found quest was like a 3-star prepared meal and I devoured it as far as I could, but the chef seemed to hate me and always put glass shards in the food so that I had to come back to it later after my gums were accustomed to the "difficulty" (Essentially I needed to level to beat a foe)

Everything combined together let to me loosing completely any inkling of the story.

A small anecdote concerning story. My friend and I felt like we managed to skip great chunks of it unwillingly. One example for this is the story around Gareth.

For me it felt as follows: [spoiler]The great leader Gareth managed to escape the prison island Fort Joy with the help of his divine acquaintances (us). Together they set sail to Reaper's Coast where Gareth's parents resided. He immediately went to his parents but Magisters seemed to have been a step ahead of him. The battle did not take long, but neither did the triumph. Beneath rubble lay two corpses ... his parents. Silently he buried them. A deep anger begins taking hold of Gareth. Before he could do anything reckless his two divine acquaintances appear. He told them what happened. The trio stood there silently. Until one divine spoke up: "It is what it is, bro".

These words quiet the anger immediately and Gareth went back to the ship never do to anything of note again.
[/spoiler] 

I do not know how one should experience his tale but this is beyond ridiculous.

This was roughly the experience I had with almost all of the story points which is why during the end credits I felt like I was being introduced to new characters since I could not for the life of me remember who any of the characters even where.

My [u]recommendation[/u] for this one would be to add more information to the journal, and to add a glossary to keep track of the different parties, their goals and what the situation currently is. The chapters setup did not help at all. It rather added to the confusion because some quests where chapter-overlapping, so they never disappeared.

[b]Gear[/b]
I had a very unique problem with gear throughout the whole game. Namely, I was often stuck with too low leveled gear because of set combos. These set combos gave me unique traits which I liked, but I could never transition smoothly to a new set due to bonuses of the set combo.

So my solution would be to upgrade my gear, but there is no way to level up gear. There is a DLC-esque bundle modifications containing the gear sisters. Which adds four sister merchants in the game which sell you (limited) quantities of gear upgrade ingredients. Even if you managed to pay their insanely steep prices (easily 10k per PIECE). Their limited quantity would not even allow you to upgrade a full set of unique gear ONCE.

I re-iterate my final gear that was a 5 piece armor set, was physically not possible to be upgraded fully ONCE even if I collected ALL the armor upgrade ingredients.

[u]Recommendation[/u]: Please let me upgrade my gear, I'm begging you.

Possibly one of the most frustrating games I've ever played. I did a full two player run with a friend on Classic difficulty, start to finish. After having played through BG3 twice and enjoying it, I expected this game to feel similar. Do not make that mistake.
This game has major balancing issues, but not combat wise, but knowledge wise. If you go into this game knowing and looking up everything, you'll probably clear it all no problem, but going into this game blind will result in you getting your ass handed to you. Surprise encounters out the wazoo, enemy immunities that can screw up a majority of builds, the physical/magical split. Oh and some of the puzzles are absolutely idiotic. Then there's the add-ons, fantastic additions if you don't care about achievements, but if you do, you gotta keep em off, which really sucks given they're all QoL things that exist to make this boring game significantly less frustrating. Want to be able to see ghosts without clicking a button? Tough luck, no achievements for you. Want to replenish a resource that isn't hard to get but takes like 20 seconds at the end of each fight to replenish at the click of a button? No achievements allowed.
Also lets talk about build variety. And how it sucks. Do you want a hybrid magic/physical guy? Enjoy gimping yourself. Heck, do you want half mage half physical team members? Enjoy gimping your team. You pretty much have to go all in on one type by the end of the game because of the game's magic/physical armour health system. Oh and you better hope you get good levelled gear on level, or your armor will be too low and this game becomes CC hell, because almost every ability has an unavoidable CC once your armor is gone.
Also by the end of the game, you better have at least 5 points in polymorph if you want to do anything, cause if you don't, good luck with your builds.
Also civil skills are stupid. Maybe if you got more points it wouldn't be as dumb, but lockpicking eats lockpicks success or failure, same with identifying, so you better have a mask of the shapeshifter or an undead in the party if you don't want to deal with that crap.
Finally, ignoring balancing issues, enemies regularly jumping out of nowhere to fight you, the fact that the game has levelled randomized loot, the weirdly rushed ending to many story arcs and the fact that the game tells you nothing, the game is broken. Numerous times, dialogues that were supposed to happen didn't, things that didn't seem like they were supposed to happen did happen, and my friend and I literally skipped the final boss because the game bugged out, and we just... didn't fight it.
All in all, this is probably one of the most frustrating games I have ever played, that punishes you with disabling achievements for trying to make the game not even easier, but a smoother experience. Also you're locked into your companions for the whole game, so you better like em once you pick em. This is a good game, but hear me out. 

This is a negative review because the game has insanely high review scores BUT it has some glaring issues. 

There's a bit of a catch though. It's the fact that I've only become frustrated enough to leave a negative review after multiple playthrough's. This is because I was so pleased with my initial experience that I was willing to overlook the issues back then. I am not willing now. 

The worst issue here is the simple fact that many fights in this game feel borderline unwinnable unless you already know how the fight will go before going into it and take steps to give yourself as much advantage as possible. This doesn't feel like "tactical" gameplay and is very frustrating, probably the most of any of the issues this game has. 

The second biggest issue is that you can really easily screw yourself over just because you talked to someone with the wrong character, which btw can be very hard to avoid in certain situations where npc's approach and initiate dialogue after a fight or something. They just go for the nearest npc and you can't well control that. If you are playing with friends, this mostly manifests as the player with the character who has persuasion having to be the one who goes first everywhere to talk to all npc's and see all new areas, otherwise you might fail some essential dialogue option. Feels like it punishes the other players for exploring.  

The rest of the issues have mostly to do with jank or bugs, like quest entries and markers not updating properly (this happens ALOT, but thankfully actual quest progression rarely breaks). But one of my biggest personal issues is the fact that many near-essential game changes that come bundled with the game and were made by the devs are treated as mods and disable your achievements. Like, really? Almost all of them are quality of life improvements that should have just been part of the base game, don't get me wrong it's extra nice to have the option, but not if it punishes you for using them. 

It's a good game, and you probably owe it to yourself to play it if you are a fan of crpg's, BUT it still has issues which may not be conveyed to you by the high review score. That's why I decided to write this.

Ah yes one final thing. Traps in this game are on a limited, short timer, which counts independent of the combat turns. They are fucking useless. Absolute garbage and waste, baffling design decision that I still struggle to comprehend. Normally I love a good use of traps in games like this (Underrail is the absolute king of this plus also stealth) but in this game it is awful. But that may be just me, cause I'm a traps enjoyer.

Not enjoying the combat system. It's doable but I don't enjoy how it creates challenge. For example pre-positioning enemies in good positions and clumping up the party (when the fight happens on a new map), setting them them up to get blasted before they can do anything. Or, just making enemies far stronger than the party members, forcing you to figure out what areas to avoid by dying and reloading. The game does a poor job explaining how things work. You get a lot of options and variables without context, and you need to pick wisely or suck. It all results in having to google how things work, and meta-gaming before fights, which is detrimental to the immersion.
Also, the game world is supremely bleak and depressing; I don't need a game for that.

I really would love to like this game. It has engaging combat, a great multiplayer and interactivity that I have not seen before.
The start at Fort Joy is amazing to play. It's the best balanced and the most well-rounded. I always knew where to go, always found new things to explore and I never felt lost story wise.

All of this starts to turn around in the following acts and I feel like it gets worse or at least more glaring the further you progress. 
These glaring issues for me are:

[b] "Open World" [/b]
On Fort Joy the open world felt rewarding. The battles were challenging but beatable. So, I was delighted to see what may come after Fort Joy.

What I ended up finding were "natural" level barriers that forced my friend and I to follow a linear route to so that we could beat the battles (note that we played on normal).
Finding this linear route after the game told us to pick and choose where we wish to go next just felt confusing. In total it took us a month to progress (we played once every week). We desperately staked out which area might be appropriate for our level 12 characters. I still remember each area of the second act and which level is associated with. 
Perhaps we where unfortunate to not have chosen this path. Mayhaps, we simply overread an important dialog pointing us towards the right direction.
The only thing I know for sure is that the only for us beatable area was [spoiler]in the top left corner[/spoiler] of the map.

You have to pass multiple other areas with higher levels to get there.
Nevertheless, this area was still a mighty struggle. We fought with everything we had. We strategized about each battle. After every loss we took notes, regrouped and attacked again. Every potential "exploit" we could see, we utilized.

This level of tenacity does not feel appropriate for a normal difficulty playthrough at least not for me.

[u]Recommendation[/u]
The pre-set levels with the exponential leveling system to not work together with the "open world" aspect of the game.
I'll get more in-depth with the leveling in the next part, but giving the player the directive to "reign freely" while setting fixed levels to the enemies does not add up. 
Adjusting the enemies to the level the player is feels way more appropriate. Maybe, sprinkle in some fixed levels as a boss to really stop the player if the story demands it, but putting this everywhere is just misguided. 

Especially since it let to us loosing track of the story completely. We started each quests, but we could never finish them due to the battles. So after a week or two we came back to the quest without having a clue of what was going on. (The in-game journal is quite lack luster on this regard)

[b]Levelling[/b]
In total you can get up to level [spoiler]21[/spoiler], which feels a little low looking at other RPGs. The issue I have with this is that you are at level [spoiler]12 when leaving Fort Joy[/spoiler]. This leads to the weird situation that levels are exponentially more important the closer you get to the max level.

At first you may be able to win a battle against a two levels higher foe, but towards the end if you are not on the same level as your enemy, you get demolished.
We literally couldn't defeat the final boss since we were one level below it. Coincidentally, we also were at a point were we felt like we completed every quest available to us. After trying for another fruitless three weeks, we loaded a previous save and tried to squeeze out another level so we have even an inkling of a chance.

As a [u]recommendation[/u] I can just offer a proper re-balancing of the later areas and a plead for general level cap increase. In the last stages of the game seeing the next level XP requirement to be in the millions is disheartening.

[b]Quest Management[/b]
A more minute point but it feels like the bad cherry on top of the issue cake. 
The in-game journal feels in-adequate to help the player remember story points and even gist's of quests. The best you can hope for is a red marker on your map, and a small to-do entry. The point of the quest, the afflicted affiliations and the severity are often not included. 

Especially after our 3-week excursion through level barrier hell, we essentially reached a point of mindless "red flag grinding". I at least felt like a zombie trying to stave my XP-hunger by any means possible. So, every found quest was like a 3-star prepared meal and I devoured it as far as I could, but the chef seemed to hate me and always put glass shards in the food so that I had to come back to it later after my gums were accustomed to the "difficulty" (Essentially I needed to level to beat a foe)

Everything combined together let to me loosing completely any inkling of the story.

A small anecdote concerning story. My friend and I felt like we managed to skip great chunks of it unwillingly. One example for this is the story around Gareth.

For me it felt as follows: [spoiler]The great leader Gareth managed to escape the prison island Fort Joy with the help of his divine acquaintances (us). Together they set sail to Reaper's Coast where Gareth's parents resided. He immediately went to his parents but Magisters seemed to have been a step ahead of him. The battle did not take long, but neither did the triumph. Beneath rubble lay two corpses ... his parents. Silently he buried them. A deep anger begins taking hold of Gareth. Before he could do anything reckless his two divine acquaintances appear. He told them what happened. The trio stood there silently. Until one divine spoke up: "It is what it is, bro".

These words quiet the anger immediately and Gareth went back to the ship never do to anything of note again.
[/spoiler] 

I do not know how one should experience his tale but this is beyond ridiculous.

This was roughly the experience I had with almost all of the story points which is why during the end credits I felt like I was being introduced to new characters since I could not for the life of me remember who any of the characters even where.

My [u]recommendation[/u] for this one would be to add more information to the journal, and to add a glossary to keep track of the different parties, their goals and what the situation currently is. The chapters setup did not help at all. It rather added to the confusion because some quests where chapter-overlapping, so they never disappeared.

[b]Gear[/b]
I had a very unique problem with gear throughout the whole game. Namely, I was often stuck with too low leveled gear because of set combos. These set combos gave me unique traits which I liked, but I could never transition smoothly to a new set due to bonuses of the set combo.

So my solution would be to upgrade my gear, but there is no way to level up gear. There is a DLC-esque bundle modifications containing the gear sisters. Which adds four sister merchants in the game which sell you (limited) quantities of gear upgrade ingredients. Even if you managed to pay their insanely steep prices (easily 10k per PIECE). Their limited quantity would not even allow you to upgrade a full set of unique gear ONCE.

I re-iterate my final gear that was a 5 piece armor set, was physically not possible to be upgraded fully ONCE even if I collected ALL the armor upgrade ingredients.

[u]Recommendation[/u]: Please let me upgrade my gear, I'm begging you.
